cards.name: Cuban Brown Anole
cards.flavorText: Native to Cuba, this anole has displaced green anoles across the U.S. Southeast since the 1940s.

cards.name: European Glass Lizard
cards.flavorText: A legless lizard, not a snake. It can drop its tail into multiple wriggling pieces to distract predators.

cards.name: Yucatan Neotropical Rattlesnake
cards.flavorText: Its venom causes neurotoxic paralysis, unlike most rattlesnakes which rely on hemotoxins.

cards.name: Frost's Iguana
cards.flavorText: Endemic to Central America, this iguana enters torpor in cold snaps and may fall frozen from tree branches.

cards.name: Galápagos Lava Lizards
cards.flavorText: Found on every major Galapagos island, each population evolved distinct colors to match its local lava rock.

cards.name: Green Anole
cards.flavorText: Females lay a single egg every two weeks throughout the breeding season, totaling up to 10 eggs per year.

cards.name: Gold Dust Day Gecko
cards.flavorText: This gecko pollinates flowers and licks nectar — one of few reptiles that acts as a pollinator.

cards.name: Golden Lancehead
cards.flavorText: Found only on Brazil's Ilha da Queimada Grande, its venom can melt flesh around the bite site.

cards.name: Cryptic Golden Tegu
cards.flavorText: Discovered in 2015 and rarely seen, this small tegu spends most of its life burrowed underground.

cards.name: Phantastic Leaf-tailed Gecko
cards.flavorText: Its body mimics a dead leaf so precisely — veins, notches, and all — that it's nearly invisible at rest.

cards.name: Pygmy Rock Monitor
cards.flavorText: At just 20 cm long, it's one of the smallest monitor lizards, hiding in rock crevices across arid Australia.

cards.name: Solomons Coral Snake
cards.flavorText: Endemic to the Solomon Islands, this burrowing elapid has some of the most potent venom per drop of any coral snake.

cards.name: Saw-scaled Viper
cards.flavorText: Kills more people than any other snake. It rubs its serrated scales together to produce a warning "sizzle" sound.

cards.name: Plumed Basilisk
cards.flavorText: Runs across water at 1.5 m/s using fringed toes that trap air pockets, earning the name 'Jesus Christ lizard.'

cards.name: Veiled Chameleon
cards.flavorText: Color change signals mood and temperature, not camouflage. Its eyes rotate independently for 360-degree vision.

params.title: Choose a creature to copy abilities from

cards.name: Central American Snapping Turtle
cards.flavorText: Its bite force exceeds 1,000 psi. Snapping turtles have been on Earth since the late Cretaceous, 80 million years.

cards.name: South American Snapping Turtle
cards.flavorText: Uses a worm-shaped lure on its tongue to bait fish directly into its open mouth — a rare example of reptile luring.

cards.name: Gaboon Viper
cards.flavorText: Holds the record for the longest fangs of any snake at 5 cm, and can deliver 600 mg of venom in one bite.

cards.name: King Brown Snake
cards.flavorText: Despite its name, it's actually an elapid, not a brown snake. It delivers the highest venom yield per bite in Australia.

cards.name: Alcedo Giant Tortoise
cards.flavorText: Galapagos giant tortoises can live over 175 years and survive a full year without food or water.

cards.name: Darwin Volcano Giant Tortoise
cards.flavorText: Thought extinct until 2019 when a female was found on the active Darwin volcano after 112 years unseen.

cards.name: Wolf Volcano Giant Tortoise
cards.flavorText: Hybridizes with other tortoise species on Wolf Volcano, creating genetically unique populations found nowhere else.

cards.name: Black Mamba
cards.flavorText: Can slither at 20 km/h and delivers enough neurotoxin in one bite to kill 10 adults within an hour.

cards.name: Papuan Monitor
cards.flavorText: One of the largest predators in New Guinea's highlands, it hunts birds, eggs, and small mammals in montane forests.

cards.name: Gharial
cards.flavorText: Its thin snout holds over 100 interlocking teeth designed exclusively for catching fish — it cannot eat larger prey.

cards.name: King Cobra
cards.flavorText: The world's longest venomous snake at 5.5 m. It primarily eats other snakes, including cobras and kraits.

cards.name: Boa Constrictor
cards.flavorText: Kills by sensing the prey's heartbeat through its coils, tightening between beats until circulation stops completely.

cards.name: Chinese Alligator
cards.flavorText: Fewer than 150 remain in the wild. Unlike most crocs, it brumates in winter burrows — the only cold-tolerant crocodilian.

cards.name: American Alligator
cards.flavorText: A keystone species — its wallowing creates wetland habitats that hundreds of other species depend on.

cards.name: American Crocodile
cards.flavorText: Tolerates saltwater thanks to specialized salt-excreting glands on its tongue, thriving in coastal mangrove estuaries.

cards.name: Black Caiman
cards.flavorText: South America's largest predator at 5+ meters. Its dark coloring absorbs heat faster for nocturnal hunting.

cards.name: Burmese Python
cards.flavorText: Invasive in Florida, it has caused a 99% decline in raccoon and opossum populations in the Everglades.

params.title: Choose a carrion predator to copy

cards.name: Green Anaconda
cards.flavorText: Weighing over 200 kg, it's the heaviest snake on Earth. It gives live birth to up to 40 young at once.

cards.name: Komodo Dragon
cards.flavorText: Confirmed venomous in 2009 — it uses venom glands in its lower jaw, not bacteria, to cause shock and blood loss.

cards.name: Nile Crocodile
cards.flavorText: Generates the strongest bite force ever measured in a living animal — over 22,000 newtons at the back teeth.

cards.name: Saltwater Crocodile
cards.flavorText: The largest living reptile at 6+ meters. It can swim over 900 km across open ocean using sea currents.

cards.name: Scythian Arrows
cards.flavorText: Scythian warriors dipped arrowheads in decomposed viper venom mixed with dung — an early form of biological warfare.

cards.name: Meteor
cards.flavorText: The Chicxulub asteroid wiped out 75% of species, but crocodilians, turtles, and snakes survived to diversify rapidly.

cards.name: Snake Wine
cards.flavorText: A real Southeast Asian drink: a venomous snake steeped in rice wine. Ethanol denatures the venom proteins, making it safe.

cards.name: Paralyze
cards.flavorText: Snake neurotoxins block acetylcholine receptors at nerve-muscle junctions, causing progressive paralysis within minutes.

params.title: Choose a Rival's creature to paralyze

cards.name: Sunshine
cards.flavorText: Reptiles bask to reach optimal body temperature — even a few degrees can double their digestion speed and reflexes.

cards.name: Ecdysis
cards.flavorText: Snakes shed their skin in one piece, including transparent eye caps. The process is triggered by thyroid hormones.

cards.name: Vengeful
cards.flavorText: Many vipers can control venom injection — 'dry bites' with no venom occur in up to 50% of defensive strikes.

params.title: Choose a creature to gain Poisonous

cards.name: Cold-blooded
cards.flavorText: Ectotherms use just 10% of the calories a same-sized mammal needs, giving reptiles an edge in resource-scarce habitats.

cards.name: Surprise
cards.flavorText: A striking snake accelerates its head at up to 100 m/s squared — faster than any mammalian predator's lunge.

cards.name: Scales
cards.flavorText: Reptile scales are made of beta-keratin, harder than mammalian hair. Crocodilian osteoderms contain bone for extra armor.

cards.name: Snake Oil
cards.flavorText: 19th-century 'snake oil' was real — Chinese water snake oil contains omega-3 fats that reduce inflammation.

cards.name: Snake Pit
cards.flavorText: Some snake species den communally — Manitoba's Narcisse pits hold up to 75,000 garter snakes in a single hibernaculum.
